questions.text: The image shows a graph plotted between the rate of reaction (on the y-axis) and substrate concentration (on the x-axis). Which of the following statements is not true regarding this plot?

choices.text: It is not seen with monomeric enzymes
The enzyme may have multiple binding sites

questions.solution:
Follows Michaelis Menten kinetics statement is not true regarding this plot. 

The given plot shows a sigmoid curve suggestive of cooperative binding of the enzymes to their substrates. This type of saturation kinetics is explained by Hill equation. 

Michaelis - Menten Kinetics:

The Michaelis - Menten equation gives the mathematical relationship between initial reaction velocity, v, and substrate concentration [S] which is as given below.

v = Vmax[S]/Km+[S]

where Km is the substrate concentration at which vi is half the maximal velocity (Vmax/2) which is reached at a particular concentration of the enzyme.

A graph showing a hyperbola is suggestive of Michaelis - Menten kinetics of the enzyme which is as follows.

For enzymes showing Michaelis - Menten kinetics, there is an increase in the rate of reaction, V, with an increase in substrate concentration till a point Vmax is reached beyond which rate of reaction shows saturation.

Hill equation:

Allosteric enzymes are those for which catalysis at the active site may be modulated by the presence of effectors at an allosteric site.

This is the exclusive property of multimeric enzymes, which have multiple binding sites for enzymes. This property is analogous to oxygen binding by haemoglobin. This is not seen in monomeric enzymes.

As Michaelis Menten equations cannot be used, the Hill equation is used to describe the kinetics of positive cooperative binding.

Allosteric enzymes have one catalytic site where the substrate binds and another separate allosteric site where the modifier binds.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy presented with jaundice, fever and mild splenomegaly. The patient is asked to get an Eosin-5’-maleimide (EMA) test which turns out to be positive. In this condition, what property of the red blood cells produces the graph (A) in the osmotic fragility curve?

SA - Surface area 

V- Volume

choices.text: Initial increase then decrease in SA/V ratio
Initial decrease then increase in SA/V ratio

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the symptoms of jaundice, fever and mild splenomegaly with a positive Eosin-5′-maleimide (EMA)–binding test, point towards the diagnosis of Hereditary spherocytosis. This can be confirmed by the right shift seen in the osmotic fragility curve which occurs due to an increased V/SA ratio.

Osmotic fragility is the ability of red blood cells to resist hemolysis when placed in increasing dilutions of saline solution. In the graph, the x-axis represents the saline concentration while the y-axis represents the percentage of red cells that have undergone hemolysis. Normal hemolysis begins at a concentration of 0.5% NaCl and is completed at a concentration of 0.3% NaCl as shown in the graph.

In Hereditary Spherocytosis, the osmotic fragility of the red blood cells is characteristically increased and they lyse more easily in a hypotonic solution than normal discoid RBCs due to the increased volume/surface area ratio. This is seen as a right shift in the osmotic fragility graph. Here hemolysis begins at a higher concentration of the saline solution. 

Decreased osmotic fragility indicates the presence of unusually flattened red cells (leptocytes) in which the RBCs have decreased volume/surface area ratio. Such changes occur in iron deficiency anaemia and thalassaemia in which the red cells with low mean cell haemoglobin (MCH) and mean cell volume (MCV) are unusually resistant to osmotic lysis. This is seen as a left shift in the osmotic fragility graph.

Hereditary spherocytosis is a type of hemolytic anaemia that is most commonly inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Mutations in α-spectrin, β-spectrin, ankyrin, band 4.2 and band 3 weaken the association of the membrane skeleton with the overlying plasma membrane, making them spheroid and less deformable. Patients usually present with anaemia, fatigue, splenomegaly, and jaundice and the age of presentation varies with the severity of the disease.

The life span of affected red cells is decreased on average to 10 to 20 days from the normal 120 days.

The peripheral smear shows numerous spherocytes which present as small, dark-staining (hyperchromic) red cells without the central zone of pallor that is present in normal red blood cells.

The diagnosis can be confirmed by the acid glycerol lysis test and the eosin-5′-maleimide (EMA)–binding test.  It is a flow cytometric test based on the interaction between the dye eosin-5-maleimide and band 3 protein.

There is no specific treatment available besides splenectomy.

questions.text: A 33-year-old lady presents with complaints of ear pain associated with impaired hearing. Further evaluation by otoscopy reveals a dull and lustreless tympanic membrane with prominent lateral process of the malleus. Which of the following curves will be obtained if she undergoes tympanometry?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical case, otoscopy findings of a dull and lustreless tympanic membrane with prominent lateral process of the malleus, are highly suggestive of a retracted tympanic membrane. On Tympanometry, a Type C tympanogram (Curve 1) with normal compliance and negative pressure is seen in the case of a retracted tympanic membrane.

Features of retracted TM:

  • TM is dull and lustreless.
  • The cone of light is absent or interrupted.
  • The handle of the malleus appears foreshortened.
  • The lateral process of the malleus becomes more prominent.
  • Anterior and posterior malleal folds become sickle-shaped.

Tympanometry: It is used in evaluating the status of the middle ear and the functioning of the eustachian tube. Results of tympanometry are plotted in the form of a tympanogram with:

  • Compliance on the Y axis (ease of mobility of TM)
  • Middle ear pressure on the X axis (regulated by eustachian tube)

Principle: When a sound wave strikes the tympanic membrane, some of the sound energy is absorbed while the rest is reflected. A stiffer tympanic membrane would reflect more sound energy than a compliant one.

Tympanometry has also been used to evaluate the function of the eustachian tube in cases of intact or perforated tympanic membrane. A pressure of —200 or +200 mm H2O is created in the middle ear and the person is asked to swallow 5 times in 20 seconds. The ability to equilibrate the pressure indicates normal tubal function. It is also used in evaluating the patency of the grommet inserted in the tympanic membrane for treating serous otitis media.

Curve 2- Type B curve. A flat or dome-shaped graph. No change in compliance with pressure changes. Seen in middle ear fluid or thick tympanic membrane.

Curve 3- Type As curve. Compliance is lower at or near ambient air pressure. Seen in otosclerosis or malleus fixation.

Curve 4- Type Ad curve. High compliance at or near ambient pressure. Seen in ossicular discontinuity or thin and lax tympanic membrane.

questions.text: In the given left ventricular pressure-volume loop, which of the following corresponds to the 'c' wave of JVP?
questions.solution:
In the given left ventricular pressure-volume loop, the event that occurs between Points B and C is iso-volumetric contraction, which corresponds to the ‘c’ wave of JVP.

In iso-volumetric contraction, the ventricular muscle continues to contract, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.

The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:

  • a wave corresponds to atrial contraction (systole) and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
  • c wave represents iso-volumetric contraction occurring in ventricular systole.
  • x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
  • v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
  • y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening, during which both the right atrium and right ventricle are in diastole. 

Related Pearl: Cardiac pressure - volume loop

The volume-pressure curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure(Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

Phase I: Period of filling (between A and B)

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction (between B and C)

Phase III: Period of ejection (between C and D)

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation (between D and A)

where,

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

 

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation

questions.text: An opioid overdose victim with severe respiratory depression was brought to the casualty. You start the patient on the most potent drug known to reverse respiratory depression in this condition. Which of the following graphs represents the action of this drug?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for the reversal of respiratory depression in opium overdose is naloxone which acts as a competitive opioid antagonist represented by graph 3.

Competitive antagonist is an agent which blocks or reduces the action of an agonist on a receptor but does not have any effect of its own. Naloxone acts on the µ receptors in the brainstem respiratory centres.

Naltrexone is also an opioid antagonist that blocks opioid effects, particularly euphoria, and discourages per­sons with opioid dependence from substance-seeking behaviour. It is not the first choice in acute opioid overdose.

Graph 1 represents the agonist: An agonist is an agent which initiates the normal physiological response when combined with a receptor. Example: Salbutamol is a beta-2 receptor agonist. 

Graph 2 represents a partial agonist: An agent which produces a submaximal or partial effect when combined with a receptor. Example: Buprenorphine and butorphanol are partial agonists at opioid receptors.
 
Graph 4 represents an inverse agonist: An agent which activates a receptor to produce an effect in the opposite direction to that of the agonist. Example: β-Carboline is an inverse agonist at the benzodiazepine site of the GABA-A receptor.
 
According to the receptor occupation theory, the ability of a drug to bind to a receptor is its affinity, and the ability to induce functional change in the receptor is designated as the intrinsic activity (IA) of the drug. These 2 properties are independent of each other.

The intrinsic activities of the above groups of drugs are given below:

Type of drugs

Related Pearl: Pure opioid antagonists

Naloxone: short-acting opioid antagonist with duration of action of 1-2 hours. Used in opioid overdose and respiratory depression in newborns due to perinatal opioid use.

Naltrexone: long-acting opioid antagonist with effects lasting till 48 hours. Used for prevention of relapse in opioid addiction treatment. It is associated with hepatotoxicity. It does not suppress craving in opioid addiction but suppresses craving in chronic alcoholics.

Nalmefene: long-acting opioid antagonist with a half-life of 8-10 hours administered intravenously. Used in opioid overdose like naloxone.

questions.text: Which of the following modes of transport follows transportation kinetics similar to that marked by the arrow in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image indicates a transportation process that shows a linear increase and does not get saturated at higher concentrations. Simple diffusion is not a carrier-mediated transport and hence, does not follow saturation kinetics.

Facilitated diffusion, primary active transport, and secondary active transport all involve integral membrane proteins and are called carrier-mediated transport. All carrier-mediated transport system follows saturation kinetics. The figure shows that as the concentration of the diffusing substance increases, the rate of simple diffusion continues to increase proportionately, but in the case of facilitated diffusion, the rate of diffusion cannot rise greater than the transport maximum (Tm). Tm is analogous to the maximum velocity (Vmax) level in enzyme kinetics.

 

Related Pearl: Characteristics of Carrier Mediated Transport

Properties Description
Stereospecificity For example- D-Glucose is transport by facilitated diffusion but not L-isomer. Simple diffusion in contrast will not distinguish between the two.
Saturation The transport rate increases as the concentration of the solute increases until the carriers are saturated (Tm).
Competition Structurally related solutes compete for transport sites on carrier molecules.

questions.text: A 5-month-old boy presents with repeated epileptic spasms. Lately, his parents noticed that he is no longer able to hold his head steadily. EEG findings are given below. On examination, ash-leaf-like hypopigmented macules on both hands and an irregularly thickened skin-coloured patch on the lower back are seen. What is the drug of choice for treating this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario of infantile spasms, developmental regression (inability to hold his head steadily) and the EEG showing hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes) are suggestive of West syndrome. The presence of ash leaf-like hypopigmented macules and an irregularly thickened skin-coloured patch on the lower back (Shagreen patch) also suggests the child has Tuberous Sclerosis. 

The drug of choice for treating this condition is Vigabatrin. Vigabatrin is a GABA uptake inhibitor that has been found to be effective in controlling infantile spasms associated with Tuberous Sclerosis. 

West syndrome starts between the ages of 2 and 12 months and is characterized by salaam spells (sudden dropping of the head or flexion of arms, followed by tonic extension of arms and legs) and hypsarrhythmia on EEG.

The image given below illustrates infantile spasms in a child-

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is considered to be the drug of choice for infantile spasms. It acts by (1) inducing steroid release and (2) a direct, steroid-independent action on melanocortin receptors. 

Tuberous sclerosis (Bourneville disease) is an autosomal dominant disease caused by mutations in either the TSC1 or the TSC2 gene. The clinical features seen are as follows: 

  • Seizures
  • Intellectual disability
  • White ovoid or ash‐leaf‐shaped macules 1–3 cm in length, most easily detectable by examination under Wood’s light, are frequently present on the trunk or limbs.
  • Adenoma sebaceum (facial angiofibromas)
  • Shagreen patch is an irregularly thickened, slightly elevated, soft, skin‐coloured plaque, usually in the lumbosacral region.
  • Periungual fibromas
  • Renal angiomyolipomas

Diagnostic Criteria for Tuberous Sclerosis- 

Major Criteria Minor Criteria
Hypomelanotic macules (≥3; at least 5mm diameter) “Confetti” skin lesions
Angiofibroma (≥3) or fibrous cephalic plaque Dental enamel pits (≥3)
Ungual fibromas (≥2) Intraoral fibromas (≥2)
Shagreen patch Retinal achromic patch
Multiple retinal hamartomas Multiple renal cysts
Subependymal nodule (≥2) Nonrenal hamartomas
Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma Sclerotic bone lesions
Cardiac rhabdomyoma  
Lymphangiomyomatosis (LAM)  
Angiomyolipomas (≥2)  


Definite TSC: either two major features or one major feature with two minor features.

Other options:

Valproate and Phenytoin act by blocking both calcium and sodium channels and are 1st line drugs used in the treatment of Generalised Tonic Clonic seizures.

questions.text: Which of the following serological titers in a patient with acute hepatitis B has been incorrectly labeled?
questions.solution:
In the given graph of serological markers, in a patient with acute hepatitis B infection curve 4 is incorrectly labeled. Curve 4 represents, IgM Anti HBc.

The parameters marked in the graph respectively include:

  1. HBsAg antigen
  2. Anti HBs
  3. Total Anti HBc
  4. IgM Anti HBc

Hepatitis B virus contains a 27-nm nucleocapsid core particle which is coded for by the C gene. The antigen expressed on the surface of the nucleocapsid core is hepatitis B core antigen (HBcAg), and its corresponding antibody is anti-HBc. Because HBcAg is intracellular and sequestered within an HBsAg coat, naked core particles do not circulate in serum, and therefore, HBcAg is not detectable routinely in the serum of patients with HBV infection.

Specific diagnosis of hepatitis B rests on the serological demonstration of the viral markers:

  • HBsAg is the first marker seen in the blood following infection and can be detected prior to the clinical manifestation and elevation of transaminases. Typically, they disappear within about two months of the start of clinical disease, but may sometimes persist for six months.
  • Anti-HBs antibodies are protective antibodies and they appear when the antigens are no longer detectable and they remain for very long periods. 
  • Anti-HBc antibody is the earliest marker seen in blood a week or two after the appearance of HBsAg. IgM anti-HBc is predominant in acute infections. Later, it is replaced by IgG anti-HBc. It remains for a lifetime and thus indicates a prior infection.
  • HBeAg appears in blood along with HBsAg or following its appearance. Circulating HBeAg is an indicator of active intrahepatic viral replication, and the presence of DNA polymerase, HBV DNA, and virions, reflect high infectivity.

Note:

  • Recovery from hepatitis B: Anti-HBsAg and Anti-HBc IgG will be positive in case of recovery.
  • History of Hepatitis B in the remote past: Anti-HBc IgG is the serological marker.
  • Chronic hepatitis with low infectivity: HBsAg, Anti-HBeAg, and Anti-HBc IgG will be positive.
  • In immunized individuals, only Anti-HBsAg will be positive.

questions.text: A young male patient presented to the casualty after a road traffic accident and was diagnosed with intracranial hemorrhage on the CT brain. He was started on hypertonic saline. Which of the following images best depict the changes in the fluid volumes after administration of the given saline?
questions.solution:
After the administration of hypertonic saline, the changes in the fluid volume occur as depicted in image 4.

The clinical features depict raised intracranial pressure due to intracranial haemorrhage. Patients are started on osmotic diuretics like mannitol or hypertonic saline to prevent cerebral swelling. The administration of the osmotic agents increases the osmolarity of the plasma. The cerebral tissues have lower osmolarity compared to the plasma. Therefore, this leads to the flow of excess water from cerebral tissues to the blood via osmosis.

Whenever hypertonic saline is added to the extracellular fluid (ECF), the extracellular osmolarity increases. It causes osmosis of water out of the cells into the extracellular compartment. Almost all the added sodium chloride remains in the extracellular compartment and fluid diffuses into the extracellular space to achieve osmotic equilibrium. The net effect is that the volume of ECF increases, the volumes of intracellular fluid (ICF) decreases, and the osmolarity of both compartments increase. 

Whenever isotonic saline is added to the extracellular fluid, the osmolarity of fluids does not change. The main effect is that it increases the ECF volume

Whenever hypotonic saline is added to ECF, the osmolarity of ECF decreases. This leads to the movement of water from the ECF to the ICF until both attain the same osmolarity. Both the intracellular and extracellular volumes are increased by the addition of hypotonic fluid, but the intracellular volume increases to a greater extent. Osmolarity decreases in both the compartments.

  • In ECF, a third specialized compartment, called the transcellular compartment (not shown in flow chart), is quantitatively small and includes the cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, pericardial, synovial, intraocular and digestive fluids. Altogether it constitutes about 1-2 L.
  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.
  • Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

questions.text:
Given below is a graph of the 24-hour levels of a hormone. Identify the correct set of conditions that stimulate the release of this hormone.
Options Glucose Free fatty Acid Amino Acid
A ↓ ↓ ↑
B ↓ ↓ ↓
C ↑ ↑ ↓
D ↑ ↓  ↓
questions.solution:
The hormone depicted in the graph shows pulsatile secretion, with an increase during strenuous exercise and early periods of sleep, indicating that it is growth hormone (GH). The conditions that stimulate the release of GH are given in option A - a decrease in blood glucose and free fatty acid levels and an increase in blood amino acid (especially arginine) levels. 

Growth hormone is secreted by the somatotropes located in the anterior pituitary. The levels of growth hormones show diurnal variation as well as variation across different age groups. Adolescents have the highest circulating levels of growth hormone, followed by children and adults. The levels are relatively low during the day and the pulsatile release of this hormone occurs during sleep.

Stimuli that increase GH secretion:

  • Exercise
  • Going to sleep
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Decreased FFA levels
  • Increased blood amino acid levels 
  • Stressful stimuli (including various psychological stresses)
  • High Protein Meal
  • Glucagon
  • Estrogens and androgens

Stimuli that decrease GH secretion:

  • Increased blood Glucose
  • Cortisol
  • Medroxyprogesterone
  • Growth hormone and IGF-I

GH can act directly on the cells or mediate its actions through insulin-like growth factors (IGF).

Actions of growth hormone:

  • Growth of cartilage, bones, and organs.
  • Increases amino acid uptake and protein synthesis in the cells and decreases protein breakdown.
  • Diabetogenic action: Increases the hepatic glucose release and decreases the glucose uptake by muscles and fat.
  • Increases fat utilization. It is ketogenic and increases circulating free fatty acid levels.

Since somatostatin inhibits the release of GH, somatostatin analogs like octreotide and lanreotide are used in the treatment of acromegaly.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with fever, hypotension, and skin rash with a tampon in situ for more than 1 week. A bacterial cause is suspected. The factor responsible for this disease is produced during which of the following phases in the bacterial growth curve?
questions.solution:
The above presentation of fever, hypotension, skin rash and presence of a retained vaginal tampon, point towards a likely diagnosis of toxic shock syndrome which mainly occurs due to toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1), produced during the stationary phase (3) of the bacterial growth curve.

Many bacteria produce secondary metabolic products such as exotoxins and antibiotics during the stationary phase of the bacterial growth curve.

Bacterial Growth Curve

When a bacterium is seeded into a suitable liquid medium and incubated, its growth follows a definite course. If bacterial counts are made at intervals after inoculation and plotted in relation to time, a growth curve is obtained. The curve shows the following phases:

  • Lag phase (Marked as 1)
    • Occurs immediately after the seeding of a culture media.
    • Cell size increases without increase in cell number. 
    •  Enzymes and metabolic intermediates required for multiplication are produced.
  • Log phase or exponential phase (Marked as 2)
    • In this phase, cells start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially or by geometric progression with time.
    • Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. 
  • Stationary phase (Marked as 3)
    • Cell division stops due to depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products.
    • It is a state of equilibrium.
    • Many bacteria produce secondary metabolic products such as exotoxins and antibiotics.
    • Cells are gram variable and show irregular staining.
  • Phase of decline (Marked as 4)
    • In this phase, the population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation, and action of autolytic enzymes.
    • Involution forms are common.

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) can occur as a result of several toxins. Toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1) is known as a superantigen produced by Staphylococcus aureus which binds to MHC class II molecules and causes T-cell stimulation leading to the overactivation of cytokines and inflammatory cells leading to toxic shock syndrome.

The clinical criteria required to diagnose TSS include fever >102 °F, erythroderma with desquamation after 1-2 weeks, hypotension, and the involvement of >3 organ systems. The laboratory diagnosis of staphylococcal TSS can be made with a Gram stain of the infected site, which would show gram-positive cocci in clusters.

Treatment of shock is the mainstay of therapy for TSS. Both fluids and pressors may be necessary. Tampons or other packing material should be promptly removed. A combination of clindamycin and semisynthetic penicillin or vancomycin is used as clindamycin is a protein synthesis inhibitor which helps reduce toxin production.

questions.text:
A statistician is working on a study about the haemoglobin status of children in an area. He plotted the frequency distribution as shown below. Which of the following statements represents this type of distribution curve?

1. The given graph shows a negatively skewed distribution.   

2. It is identified by the hump of the curve. 

3. It represents asymmetric frequency distribution.

4. In this scenario, mean < median < mode.

5. Mean divides the distribution into two equal halves under the curve.
questions.solution:
The image given shows a negatively skewed distribution where mean < median < mode. 

Skewed distributions are the ones that have asymmetric frequency distributions. They can be identified as positive (right) or negative (left) according to the location of the tail of the curve and not by the location of the hump. In the image, the tail is located on the negative side of the graph (left side) so it is a negative or left-skewed distribution.

In any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution into two equal halves under the curve.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: If the cutoff value of the given screening test is changed from point B to point A, what will happen to the negative and positive predictive values, respectively?
questions.solution:
As the cutoff point shifts from point B to point A, the test's negative predictive value increases and the positive predictive value decreases.

In the given diagram

TN- True negative, FN- False negative, FP- False positive, TP- True positive

Negative predictive value (NPV) is the proportion of negative results that are true negatives, that is, the possibility that a person with a negative test does not have the condition.

NPV = TN/(TN+FN), as False Negative(FN) decreases in the above case, NPV will increase.

Positive predictive value (PPV) is the proportion of positive results that are true positives, that is, the possibility that a person with a positive test result truely has the disease

PPV = TP / (TP + FP), as False Positive (FP) increases in the above case, PPV will decrease.

When the cutoff value is decreased by changing the cutoff towards Point A, the test will now identify everyone with the disease and thus have a very high sensitivity. But at this point, the test would also incorrectly diagnose many healthy individuals as diseased. Therefore, the number of false positive results would also be high, and thus the specificity decreases.

Opposite trends will be seen when the cutoff shifts towards point C, leading to higher specificity but low sensitivity with an increase in PPV and a decrease in NPV. 

Thus, the cutoff points of screening tests are very meticulously chosen to maintain high enough specificity and sensitivity both for clinical practice.

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with right-sided sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. On examining his ear, you notice numbness in the posterosuperior meatal wall of the external auditory canal. Which of the following speech audiometric graphs represents this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, symptoms of unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus and numbness in the posterosuperior meatal wall of the external auditory canal (Hitzelberger sign) are highly suggestive of Acoustic Neuroma which shows the characteristic roll-over phenomenon (Graph D), in speech audiometry.

In speech audiometry, the patient’s ability to hear and understand speech is measured. Speech reception threshold and discrimination score/score percentage are studied under this test. The speech reception threshold is the lowest intensity of sound at which 50% of the words are repeated correctly by the patient, and the discrimination score is the percentage of test words correctly repeated by the patient and is calculated as follows:

If a 50-word list is used, 2% is given for each correct response, and if a 25-word list is used, 4% is given for each correct response.

The Roll-over phenomenon is seen on plotting the discrimination score against the amplitude of the sound. It is a feature of retro-cochlear/neural lesions wherein the speech discrimination steadily increases with intensity but suddenly drops significantly beyond a particular intensity of sound due to nerve fatigue.

Acoustic neuroma is also called vestibular schwannoma or neurilemmoma, or eighth nerve tumor. It arises from the Schwann cells of the vestibular nerve. It is the most common cerebellopontine angle tumor and is associated with neurofibromatosis 2. It is common in both sexes between 40-60 years of age. 

Clinically, patients typically present with progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss with tinnitus. Involvement of other cranial nerves results in the following symptoms:

  • Trigeminal nerve: reduced corneal sensitivity, numbness, or paraesthesia of the face.
  • Facial nerve: hypoaesthesia of the posterior meatal wall called Hitzelberger’s sign.
  • Glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve: Dysphagia and hoarseness.

Central nuclear-free zones ratified by the palisading of nuclei, termed Verocay bodies are found in schwannomas. 

MRI with gadolinium contrast is the gold standard for diagnosis. It shows an ice cream cone appearance.

The treatment of choice is the surgical removal of the tumor. Stereotactic radiosurgery, like X-knife or gamma knife surgery, is used for people who refuse/ cannot tolerate surgery.

Other options:

Graph A- seen in a patient with normal hearing.

Graph B- seen in conductive deafness.

Graph C- seen in cochlear disorders like Meniere's disease, will rather show a plateau after a certain level, unlike the fall seen in the roll-over phenomenon. 

Related Pearl: Speech audiometry

Consists of two components:

  • Speech reception threshold: The minimum intensity at which 50% of the words are repeated correctly by the patient.
  • Speech discrimination score: The patient’s ability to understand speech.
    • Percentage of phonetically balanced words delivered 30dB above SRT which are identified correctly.
    • In normal persons and those with conductive hearing loss, a high score of 90–100% can be obtained.
    • It is reduced in cochlear lesions, very poor and out of proportion to hearing loss in retrocochlear hearing loss, and worst in cortical deafness.

Roll-over phenomenon:

  • Feature of retrocochlear hearing loss.
  • When speech intensity is increased above a particular level, SDS falls instead of maintaining a plateau as in cochlear deafness.

Uses:

  • To differentiate organic from non-organic hearing loss.
  • To differentiate cochlear from retrocochlear lesions.
  • To find the intensity at which discrimination score is the best which is useful for fitting a hearing aid.

*Short Increment Sensitivity Index: A normal ear can’t differentiate short increments of sound but a recruiting ear can. SISI test is started sound 20db above the hearing threshold of the patient and 20 increments of 1db are given every 5 seconds. The total number of increments heard by the patient is recorded. SISI score of 70-100% is seen in cochlear deafness and of 0-20% in retrocochlear deafness.

** Threshold tone decay: It is a function of nerve fatigue. A Tone of 4000Hz is presented at 5dB above the patient’s threshold of hearing for 60 seconds. A normal ear can hear continuously for a minute but a patient with abnormal hearing stops hearing before 1 minute. Loudness is increased until the patient can hear the sound. If loudness has to be increased by more than 30dB, it indicates retrocochlear hearing loss.

questions.text: A primigravida at 34 weeks of gestation presented with sudden-onset abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination uterine tenderness is present along with frequent contractions. You advise for a cardiotocography to be done which shows the following findings. All of the following conditions are considered differentials except?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the symptoms of sudden-onset abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding along with the presence of uterine tenderness and frequent contractions on examination, point towards the diagnosis of placental abruption. The given cardiotocograph shows decelerations that begin after the onset of the uterine contraction called late decelerations/ Type II Dips, which is associated with placental abruption. It is also seen in cases of injudicious use of oxytocin, postmaturity and spinal anaesthesia. Severe Fetomaternal haemorrhage is associated with the sinusoidal pattern on cardiotocography.

Baseline variability is observed in many conditions such as:

1. Acceleration: Transient increase in fetal heart rate (FHR) by 15 bpm or more, lasting for at least 15 seconds. It denotes intact neurohormonal and cardiovascular activity and, therefore, a healthy fetus.

2. Deceleration: Transient decrease in FHR below the baseline by 15 bpm or more and lasting ≥15 seconds. Three basic types of deceleration are early, late, and variable:

Feature Early deceleration/Type I Dips Late deceleration/Type II Dips Variable deceleration
The pattern of heart rate fall

Gradual decline and gradual recovery of heart rate.

The maximum dip of the deceleration corresponds with the peak of the contraction. 

Symmetrical and gradual decline in heart rate.

Begins after the onset of the uterine contraction.

Onset, maximum dip, and recovery occur after the onset, peak, and recovery of contraction respectively.

Abrupt fall in the heart rate.   

Decelerations are variable in respect of the size, shape, depth, duration, and timing of uterine contractions.
Time taken to reach the maximum dip of deceleration  >30seconds  >30seconds  <30 seconds
Causes Fetal head compression

i) Placental pathology (postmaturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption);

(ii) Excessive uterine contractions;

(iii) Injudicious use of oxytocin; (iv) Regional anaesthesia (spinal or epidural)

 Umbilical cord compression

 

Sinusoidal pattern: It resembles a sine wave. It has a stable baseline FHR with fixed or absent baseline variability lasting >20 min. Accelerations are absent. It is often associated with fetal anaemia and fetomaternal haemorrhage. It may occur when narcotics are given to the mother. Such FHR patterns are called pseudo-sinusoidal as the fetus is well-oxygenated.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: A 24-year-old man with type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with vomiting, abdominal pain, and a respiratory rate of 36 breaths/min. His breath has a fruity odor and his urine Rothera test is positive. The results of his ABG analysis will fall under which of the following areas given in the graph below?
questions.solution:
The presence of fruity-smelling breath and a positive Rothera test in a type 1 diabetic patient, points to the diagnosis of Diabetic Ketoacidosis(DKA). In the given acid-base nomogram, the area marked F corresponds to acidic pH with decreased HCO3- levels, suggesting metabolic acidosis which is the acid-base disorder associated with Diabetic ketoacidosis. Elevated respiratory rate indicates the hyperventilatory response leading to compensatory respiratory alkalosis (area marked D). 

An acid-base nomogram, also known as a Davenport diagram, is a graphical representation of acid-base balance to interpret arterial blood gas (ABG) results. It helps determine the primary acid-base disorder and identify compensatory mechanisms. It is plotted as arterial HCO3- against arterial blood pH.

Diabetic ketoacidosis is an acute complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. The symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain.

In DKA, insulin to glucagon ratio is decreased which promotes gluconeogenesis, glycogenolysis, and ketone body formation in the liver. Ketone bodies exist as ketoacids at physiologic pH which are neutralized by bicarbonate. As bicarbonate stores are depleted, metabolic acidosis ensues. Increased lactic acid production also contributes to acidosis.

Compensatory responses for primary metabolic disorders move the PCO2 in the same direction as the change in HCO3-. Therefore, the hyperventilation response leading to compensatory respiratory alkalosis causes a decrease in the PCO2, which is in line with the decrease in HCO3-. The pH, however, remains acidic as compensatory responses only bring the pH closer to normal and usually do not completely normalize it. 

The diagnostic biochemical criteria for DKA includes:

  • Hyperglycemia (>200 mg/dL)
  • Venous pH <7.3 or plasma/serum bicarbonate <15 mmol/L
  • Ketonemia (beta-hydroxybutyrate [BOHB] >3 mmol/L) and ketonuria

Signs:

  • Kussmaul breathing (deep, heavy, non-labored rapid breathing)
  • Fruity breath odor (acetone)
  • Tachycardia
  • Dehydration
  • Hypotension

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: In the given nerve action potential curve, which point represents the beginning of the slow return of K+ channels to the closed state?
questions.solution:
Point E in the given nerve action potential curve represents the beginning of the slow return of the K+ channels to the closed state also called after-hyperpolarization.

The sequence of events occurring during an action potential is shown below 

  • Point A represents the resting state where both channels are closed. 
  • Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus and sodium enters the cell. The initiation of action potential occurs only after a certain potential is reached, called the threshold potential represented by point B.
  • After this, the sodium influx causes the opening of more Na+ channels through a positive feedback mechanism. Rapid depolarization occurs to reach point C.
  • At point C, Na+ channels close and K+ channels open, causing repolarization due to K+ efflux. 
  • Point D represents continued repolarization due to potassium efflux.
  • From point E, the K+ channels slowly return to the closed state, causing after-hyperpolarization. Na+ channels are reset and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus.
  • As both channels close, the membrane returns to resting membrane potential back to point A.

Point B-D is a part of the refractory period. During this period, the application of even a stronger stimulus will not elicit an action potential.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of dry cough, dyspnea and chest x-ray showing the characteristic garland triad. Her pulmonary function test will most likely resemble which of the following curves?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient's symptoms of dry cough and dyspnea along with the chest x-ray showing the garland triad are characteristic of Sarcoidosis which shows a restrictive pattern on the flow-volume curve, represented by curve 4.   

Sarcoidosis presents with ventilatory restriction due to increased elastic recoil. It is characterized by a decrease in total lung capacity and vital capacity, hence, the loop shrinks or narrows and shifts toward the right as seen in curve 4 in comparison to curve 1 which represents the normal flow-volume curve.

Increased flow occurs as the increased lung recoil drives greater maximal flow at any lung volume and also because airway diameters are relatively increased due to greater radially outward traction exerted on bronchi by the stiff lung parenchyma.  

In restrictive diseases, both FEV1 (Forced expiratory volume in the first second) and FVC (forced vital capacity) are reduced but FEV1/FVC ratio is normal or increased as FVC is reduced to a greater degree due to decreased compliance.

An FEV1/FVC ratio > 0.7 signifies restrictive lung disorder, whereas <0.7 is seen in obstructive diseases.

Curve 2 is an obstructive pattern of the flow-volume curve with a concave upward pattern in the expiratory limb. This is also called a scooped-out or coved pattern and is observed in conditions responsible for airflow obstruction like asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. 

Curve 3 shows a fixed upper airway obstruction pattern, seen in tracheal stenosis. In this condition, there is obstruction and limitation of airflow during both inspiration and expiration, leading to the flattening of both the inspiratory and expiratory limbs of the flow-volume loop.

Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory disease characterized by the presence of noncaseating granulomas. The disease is often multisystemic and requires the presence of involvement in two or more organs for a specific diagnosis. Lungs are most commonly affected.

Respiratory complaints including cough and dyspnea are the most common presenting symptoms. In many cases, the patient presents with a 2- to 4-week history of these symptoms.

The characteristic pattern of lymph node enlargement that is seen in this condition is known as the Garland triad or 1-2-3 sign or pawnbroker's sign. The lymph nodes involved are:

  1. Right paratracheal nodes
  2. Right hilar nodes
  3. Left hilar nodes

questions.text: In a study of a group of 40 people, a physiologist is studying the pacemaker actions of the sinoatrial node and the action potentials of each one of them were plotted in the graph given below. The ion channels predominantly responsible for the phase 0 marked in the graph is?
questions.solution:
The ion channels predominantly responsible for phase 0 marked in the graph is the L-type calcium channels. 

The graph in the given image represents the action potential of the SA (sinoatrial) node (i.e., the pacemaker potential). In the figure, phase 0 corresponds to the impulse/upstroke and, this is predominantly due to the opening of 'L' (long-acting) type of calcium channels resulting in an intracellular movement of the calcium ions down its electrochemical gradient.

The resting membrane potential (RMP) of the SA node is -55 to-60 millivolts. Phases of this potential are: 

  • Phase 0 - Upstroke wave. It is due to the influx of Ca2+ ions by the opening of voltage-gated L-type channels.
  • Phase 3 - Downstroke wave. It is due to the efflux of K+ leading to repolarization.
  • Phase 4- Prepotential. Because of ongoing K+ efflux, hyperpolarization sets in. This makes the channel more permeable to Na+ ions and since these Na+ channels are activated during hyperpolarization they are referred to as funny currents (Ih/ If). They form the first half of the pre-potential. The second half of the prepotential is completed by the opening of the voltage-gated T-(transient) type Ca2+ channel. The slope of Phase 4 in the SA node determines the heart rate. 

Clinical aspect:

i) Vagal stimulation activates the cholinergic fibres to the SAN and leads to a decreased slope of phase 4. This occurs by depolarizing effect of funny Na+ (If) channel on M2 receptor stimulation. There is also decreased cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) causing the decreased firing of the T-type Ca2+ channel. Similar action is seen upon administering digitalis. 

ii) The frequency of SA node discharge is increased when the temperature rises. Thus, fever is usually associated with tachycardia.

questions.text:
ECG findings of a patient with first degree heart block is given below. Which of the following conditions will result in the same change in the PR interval as shown below?
  1. Third-degree heart block
  2. Wenckebach block
  3. Hyperkalemia
  4. Second-degree heart block (Mobitz II)
  5. Wolff Parkinson White syndrome
questions.solution:
In first-degree AV block, a prolonged PR interval (of over 200 ms) is seen which indicates a slowing of conduction between the atria and ventricles, usually due to slow conduction through the atrioventricular node (AV node). Wenckebach block and hyperkalemia also show a prolongation in the PR interval.

PR interval is the period, measured in milliseconds, that extends from the beginning of the P wave (the onset of atrial depolarization) until the beginning of the QRS complex (the onset of ventricular depolarization); Normal duration is 0.12-0.20s.

Second-degree AV block involves intermittent failure of conduction between the atrium and ventricle. There are two subtypes of second-degree AV block:

  • Type I/Mobitz I/Wenckebach block: progressive prolongation of the PR interval until loss of conduction occurs. The patient is hemodynamically stable, and in the absence of symptoms, pacemaker is not required.
  • Type II/Mobitz II: fixed PR interval precedes loss of conduction Usually associated with QRS widening. Type II block has more serious implications, including the risk of sudden death. Permanent pacing is required.
Hyperkalemia is a plasma K+ concentration >5.5 meq/L. Common causes include acidosis, the use of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, and β2-antagonists. 
ECG changes include tall T waves, prolonged PR intervals, and small P waves. In severe cases, wide QRS complexes which progress to an undulating pattern (sine wave) and asystole can be seen.

Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is a congenital condition involving the presence of an abnormal accessory electrical conduction pathway called the Bundle of Kent between the atria & ventricles.

Accessory pathways are abnormal connections that allow conduction between the atrium and ventricles across the AV ring. They are present from birth and are due to the failure of complete partitioning of the atrium and ventricle by the fibrous AV rings

ECG shows a short P-R interval <120 ms and a slurred initial upstroke of QRS complex referred to as the delta wave.
